summary: This is an internal email chain from the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York (USAO-SDNY) containing a draft urgent matter report. The report outlines the office's plan to indict Jeffrey Epstein on federal sex trafficking charges, detailing the pattern of abuse and the legal rationale for proceeding despite a prior non-prosecution agreement from Florida.

persons.name: Geoffrey S. Berman
persons.context: Identified as the District Point of Contact (POC) for the USAO-SDNY in the draft report, which outlines the plan to indict Jeffrey Epstein.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The subject of the investigation and planned indictment for sex trafficking of minors and conspiracy to commit sex trafficking, based on abuse alleged to have occurred in New York and Florida from at least 2002 to 2005.

events.title: Planned Indictment of Jeffrey Epstein
events.description: The USAO-SDNY plans to seek an indictment against Jeffrey Epstein on one count of sex trafficking of a minor and one count of conspiracy to commit sex trafficking of a minor.

events.title: Start of Alleged Abuse Pattern
events.description: Beginning in at least 2002, Epstein allegedly enticed and recruited dozens of minor girls to engage in sex acts with him at his New York and Palm Beach residences in exchange for money.

events.title: End of Charged Conduct Period
events.description: The alleged sexual abuse and trafficking by Jeffrey Epstein continued up to and including in or about 2005, according to the planned charges.

events.title: Enactment of 18 U.S.C. § 1594
events.description: The statute for conspiring to commit sex trafficking (18 U.S.C. § 1594) was enacted. As the charged conduct predates this, the USAO-SDNY plans to use 18 U.S.C. § 371 for the conspiracy charge.

events.title: Revision of Statute of Limitations
events.description: 18 U.S.C. § 3283 was revised to permit the prosecution of sex offenses against minors at any time during the lifetime of the minor victim, enabling the prosecution of Epstein's older conduct.

locations: New York, New York (the 'New York Residence')

keyFacts: The U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York (USAO-SDNY) planned to indict Jeffrey Epstein on July 2, 2019, for sex trafficking of a minor and conspiracy.

The charges stem from Epstein's alleged sexual abuse of dozens of minor girls from at least 2002 to 2005 at his residences in New York City and Palm Beach, Florida, using a 'massage' recruitment scheme.
The document states that three specific victims, who also recruited other girls for Epstein, have described the pattern of abuse.
The USAO-SDNY argues that a prior non-prosecution agreement (NPA) from the Southern District of Florida does not bind their office and does not cover the New York-based victims central to their case.

The legal strategy involves using a revised statute of limitations law from April 2003 and charging conspiracy under 18 U.S.C. § 371, as the specific sex trafficking conspiracy statute (18 U.S.C. § 1594) was enacted after the alleged conduct.
